thread.title: Biloxi's Block Party a smash; three days of Cruisin' in Ocean Springs begins Thursday
thread.title_full: Biloxi's Block Party a smash; three days of Cruisin' in Ocean Springs begins Thursday | NOLA.com

author: Warren Kulo | wkulo@al.com
title: Biloxi's Block Party a smash; three days of Cruisin' in Ocean Springs begins Thursday
text:
BILOXI, Mississippi -- Hundreds of classic cars and thousands of spectators flocked into downtown Biloxi as the city's annual Cruisin' the Coast Block Party got underway Wednesday morning.
The overwhelming success of the block party in past years prompted city officials to rearrange the footprint for the block party to include Main Street and use of the vacant lot where a car dealership once stood.
"We've had chamber of commerce weather and a tremendous turnout," said Biloxi Mayor Andrew "FoFo" Gilich. "There's a huge number of cars here -- more than ever before -- especially with the reconfiguration and the use of the Dees (Chevrolet) lot.
"We're really tickled," Gilich said, adding that he had walked the entire footprint of the block party helping judge cars for a Cruisin' contest.
Spectators were equally enthused.
"This is such a great venue for this," said Charles Wright of Poplarville, who said he has been attending Cruisin' the Coast with fellow car enthusiasts for several years. "Downtown Biloxi and downtown Ocean Springs are by far the best Cruisin' spots, in my opinion."
Television personality Courtney Hansen signed autographs in a booth set up just outside Biloxi City Hall and live music was played at the base of the steps to city hall. Various vendors were also set up around the downtown area.
Cruisin' the Coast registration director Chris Smilek said shortly after 5 p.m. Wednesday that 217 more Cruisers had registered, bringing the total to 7,214 -- leaving just 80 more to go to break last year's record of 7,293.
"Registration will be busy Thursday and we'll get quite a few more on Friday," Smilek said. "I'm thinking we're going to end up somewhere in the 7,600 range."
Attention turns to Ocean Springs Thursday, when three days of Cruisin' the Coast begin in the lone Cruisin' venue in Jackson County. City alderman Chic Cody, who is the city's Cruisin' coordinator, said they are prepared for the onslaught expected to arrive.
"We're expecting a lot more people this year," Cody said. "Last time I checked, they were already close to 7,200 registered Cruisers. There's not much doubt it's going to be more than we've ever seen."
Cody said the city has taken steps to help alleviate parking issues in the downtown area, much of which will be closed off to all vehicles other than registered Cruisers. The city has secured the use of private property to provide parking for downtown merchants displaced by the Cruisers.
Others, including local business owners, have offered their parking lots, as well.
"We've had a lot of cooperation and support from our merchants," Cody said. "They have really done a lot to encourage the Cruisers to come. We want them coming back for years to come."
In addition to Ocean Springs, Cruisin' venues in Bay St. Louis, Pass Christian, Edgewater Mall and D'Iberville will be open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Thursday.
Thursday's Cruisin' activities include the Vicari Auto Auction at the Mississippi Coast Coliseum & Convention Center and a Country Cruisin' Breakfast at the Long Beach Yacht Club from 7 a.m. to 10 a.m.
Thursday's other events:
Swap Meet/Manufacturer's Midway on the grounds of the Mississippi Coast Coliseum from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Car Corral opens and vehicle check-in begins east of Treasure Bay casino, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Television personality Courtney Hansen will make appearances in Pass Christian from 10 a.m. to noon and in Bay St. Louis from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Entertainment in Ocean Springs, presented on the stage off Cash Alley, will include:
Mr. Saxman -- 11 a.m. to noon Halfway Ray (Ray Charles Tribute) -- 1 p.m. to 2 p.m. Ron Adams Show -- 3 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.
